perturbation.original_text:
XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving thirty (30) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.changed_text:
XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving ten (10) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination notice period to 10 days could be considered unreasonable and a violation of standard business practices and potentially conflict with Hong Kong's contract law principles of fairness and reasonableness, which often implies a longer notice period for significant agreements. What is considered a reasonable time depends on the contract. However, in most cases, it could be between 30 and 90 days.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Hong Kong's contract law principles of fairness and reasonableness.

perturbation.original_text:
Either Party may terminate this Agreement:
     (b)  if the other Party commits a material breach of this Agreement which
          is capable of being remedied but not remedied within thirty (30) days
          upon receiving written notice from the non-breaching party requiring
          remedy; and
perturbation.changed_text:
Either Party may terminate this Agreement:
     (b)  if the other Party commits a material breach of this Agreement which
          is capable of being remedied but not remedied within ten (10) days
          upon receiving written notice from the non-breaching party requiring
          remedy; and
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach to 10 days is likely to be viewed as too short and unreasonable. Most jurisdictions consider a 30-day cure period to be the standard and fair practice. This may be considered a violation of Hong Kong’s contract law principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Hong Kong’s contract law principles of fairness and reasonableness.

perturbation.original_text:
Any notice, demand or other communication so addressed to the
     relevant Party shall be deemed to have been delivered (a) if given or made
     by letter by hand, when actually delivered to the relevant address against
     receipt; (b) if given or made by letter by post, two business days after
     posting; and (c) if given or made by fax, when dispatched and received in
     good order.
perturbation.changed_text:
Any notice, demand or other communication so addressed to the
     relevant Party shall be deemed to have been delivered (a) if given or made
     by letter by hand, when actually delivered to the relevant address against
     receipt; (b) if given or made by letter by post, one business day after
     posting; and (c) if given or made by fax, when dispatched and received in
     good order.
perturbation.explanation: Assuming that notice by post is deemed to have been delivered one business day after posting can be problematic. Hong Kong postal services are generally reliable, but delays can occur. Therefore, stating only one business day may not be appropriate. Therefore, it may conflict with Hong Kong's contract law principles of fairness and reasonableness.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Hong Kong’s contract law principles of fairness and reasonableness.
